title: Are fields zero at same point

content.question: Two isolated particles, <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, lie along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. The particles have the same net charge <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, but different masses with <math alttext="M sub A is greater than M sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is there a point along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis where both the net electric field and net gravitational field of the particles are zero, and if so, in what region is the point?

choices.label: No, there is no point on the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis where both the fields are zero.

content.answer: No, there is no point on the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis where both the fields are zero.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
